title: Understanding Expressions
text:
In order to understand expressions, we have to break the expression down into its terms. A term is a group of constants (numbers) and variables (like \(x\)) combined together with various operators like \(\times\) and \(\div\). An expression is simply a set of terms that are joined together by binary operators \(+\) and \(-\). Here are a few examples of terms and expressions.
Terms
\(4x\)
\(12\)
\(y^2\)
\(\frac{7}{12}\)
Expressions
\(4 + x\)
\(6 - k\)
\(y - x^2\)
\(6x-2y\)

title: Examples of expressions
text:
Let's build an expression from the examples above. All we have to do is combine the terms using \(+\) and/or \(-\) $$4x + 12 + y^2 - \frac{7}{12}$$ Easy right ? Here are a few more examples of expressions.
\(x^2 - x + 1\)
\(xy - x + 5\)
\(0 + 23\)

title: Evaluating Expressions
text:
Now for the fun part. For completeness, we are going to evaluate two different kinds of expressions.

Let's start with an expression without variables.
$$5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1$$
When evaluating an expression with no variables, we can simply evaluate by applying BEDMAS.

$$\begin{aligned}
5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1 &= 5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1 &&\text{Exponent}\\
&= 5 + 4\times 8 - 1 &&\text{Multiplication}\\
&= 5 + 32 - 1 &&\text{Addition}\\
&= 37 - 1 &&\text{Subtraction}\\
&= 36 &&\text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Good stuff. Now let's evaluate an expression with variables.

$$\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 5x + 8 &&\text{at $x = 3$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

We have to perform an additional step at the start before we can evaluate, which is to substitute the value given for the variable, in this case \(3\) for \(x\). 

Then evaluate like a simple expression by applying BEDMAS.

$$\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 5x + 8 &= (3)^2 - 5(3) + 8 && \text{substitute in 3 wherever you see $x$}\\
&= 3^2 - 5 \times 3 + 8 &&\text{Exponent}\\
&= 9 - 5 \times 3 + 8 &&\text{Multiplication}\\
&= 9 - 15 + 8 &&\text{Subtraction (since it comes before Addition)}\\
&= -6 + 8 &&\text{Addition}\\
&= 2 &&\text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

That's it! Now you know how to evaluate an expression. Practice these concepts in the Exercise section below.

title: Let's Apply What We Learned
text:
Now that we've gone over some examples of expressions and we learned how to evaluate them, let's finish this tutorial off by discussing the value of knowing how to evaluate expressions.

To start, it's fair to say that if we were given an expression without context of what it represents, then we wouldn't really learn very much by evaluating it, besides how to evaluate it of course. 

However, if I was to give you an equation (which is simply a combination of terms and expressions), say \(M = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh\) which is the equation of finding the mechanical energy of an object with mass \(m\), velocity \(v\) and height \(h\). By simply evaluating the expresssion:  \(\frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh\) we could determine the amount of mechanical energy relative to that object.

Let's apply everything we just learned into finding the mechanical energy of a  bowling ball rolling down a bowling alley.

$$\text{Suppose we were given a bowling ball that has a mass $m = 4$kg}$$
$$\text{Find the amount of mechanical energy present when we roll the bowling ball down the alley at a velocity of 4m/s.}$$
To start, let's define the values for our variables

\(
\begin{aligned}
m &= 4~\text{kg}\\
v &= 4~\text{m/s}\\
g &= 9.8~\text{m/s} && \text{$g$ represents the gravitational constant}\\
h &= 0~\text{m} && \text{h represents the height/distance of the bowling ball relative to the ground/bowling alley}\\
\end{aligned}\)
$$
\begin{aligned}
M &= \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh && \text{substitute in our values for $m,v,g$ and $h$}\\
M &= \frac{1}{2}(4)(4)^2 + (4)(9.8)(0) && \text{}\\
M &= 2\cdot 16 + 0\\
M &= 32~\text{J} && \text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

So what we learned by evaluating the expression was that the amount of mechanical energy that is present when rolling a bowling ball that weighs \(4~\text{kg}\) down a bowling alley at a velocity of \(4~\text{m/s}\) is 32 Joules (J).
